title: Custom Satin Colum Will Not Render the First Few Times
body:
Hi,

I have a custom satin column in my file that when I set it with params, the screen doesn't refresh and still shows the running stitch (the default). I'll close and reopen a few times and sometimes it'll work. Other times, it is a combination of copying a section of the column (and rails) into a new file, make it render, then at some point, the entire column will render without any problems or modifications. 

Do you know why this is happening? Is there a cache or something? 

thanks
  Matt

title: Clones are broken in 2.2.0
body:
With the last release we managed to break the clone functionality comepletely:

- attribtues of the original element are not taken over to the clone anymore
- fill rotation angle isn't calculated correctly
- positioning of the rendered clone element is sometimes wrong

At first I wanted to fix it in one of the open pull requests, but this is a little bit more than I anticipated at first.
I think this should be in it's own PR. Also I didn't manage to fix things completely yet.

title: Inconsistent running stitch length on pre-release
body:
I was concerned by the strange sounds my machine was making, like the motor wasn't running at a consistent speed, until I realized it was that the *stitches* aren't a consistent length. Params are set to 2.5mm, and that's a little complicated by the fact that it's also repeat-2 (so there's two runs of stitching there), but it definitely slows down and speeds up based on curve tightness.

![IMG_1722](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9473609/170886377-f55bab19-1bb0-4ebf-a4ca-09e003a65c01.jpeg)

I am 90% sure I'm running this release, https://github.com/inkstitch/inkstitch/releases/tag/dev-build-kall-test
but I'm about to go give https://github.com/inkstitch/inkstitch/releases/tag/dev-build-kaalleen-guided_ripple
a shot.

title: Removing commands fails when there is no layer in the document
body:
The remove embroidery settings functions fails for commands when there is no layer in the document.

If there is a layer present, but the Command group has been ungrouped, it will also remove the whole group (with every other object within the parent group).

Reference: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MWGm6gxblbg&t=30m

title: Pattern mode workings

labels.name: investigate
labels.description: Issues that adress a hipothesis or need further insights in order to be resolved

labels.name: help: docs
labels.description: Issue calls for documentation to be written on the wiki!

body:
Hi
I am playing with the great new pattern feature. **Patterns made from strokes do behave as expected** (as far as I can judge), i.e. points are generated where the strokes meet the ones from the fill.
According to the documentation, " pattern consists of strokes or fill areas (or both at the same time). Strokes will be used to add stitches, while patterns with a fill will remove stitches from the embroidery element."

**Patterns made from fills do not seem to work as expected**, i.e. only the first subpath seems to be taken into account. I point to two sample svg files (plus a simulation made with truesizer), one with a pattern that includes both strokes and fills and the other with only fills. In both cases only one subpath is filled, i.e. the one that sits in the upper right of the rice cracker.

So question: Is this a bug or by design (i.e. a "fill" pattern can only be a single shape) ?

1. http://tecfa.unige.ch/guides/embroid/emoji/AAA_EMOJIS/food_drink/food-asian/rice-cracker-twemoji-inkstitch.svg
2. http://tecfa.unige.ch/guides/embroid/emoji/AAA_EMOJIS/food_drink/food-asian/rice-cracker-twemoji-inkstitch.PNG
2. http://tecfa.unige.ch/guides/embroid/emoji/AAA_EMOJIS/food_drink/food-asian/rice-cracker-twemoji-inkstitch-fills.svg
3. http://tecfa.unige.ch/guides/embroid/emoji/AAA_EMOJIS/food_drink/food-asian/rice-cracker-twemoji-inkstitch-fills.PNG

title: Palette installation and use problems under Ubuntu (Debian)
body:
Hello, super kudos first for the new version :)

I installed the Debian package v2.1.0 on my Ubuntu 18. It was installed in /opt/inkstitch When I tried to install my own palette I got this error:
-----
Ink/Stitch ne peut pas automatiquement trouver votre dossier de palette . Veuillez installer votre palette manuellement.
Ink/Stitch a connu une erreur inattendue.

Si vous souhaitez nous aider à résoudre ce problème, veuillez soumettre un problème à https://github.com/inkstitch/inkstitch/issues et inclure la description complète de l'erreur ci-dessous :

Ink/Stitch Version: v2.1.0 (linux)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "inkstitch.py", line 62, in <module>
  File "inkex/base.py", line 147, in run
  File "lib/extensions/install_custom_palette.py", line 38, in effect
  File "shutil.py", line 261, in copyfile
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/opt/inkstitch/bin/palettes/InkStitch Emoji Gunold No.gpl'
----

Then it got more messy (sorry I may have skipped a detail since I was eager to get it done ....)

I then installed the InkStitch Palettes and had to change permissions to the required directory. After that, InkStitch could not find this /opt/inkstitch/bin/palettes/ directory (alias /usr/share/inkscape/extensions/inkstitch/bin/palettes) since palettes are supposed to be in an inkscape directory, i.e. ~/.config/inkscape/palettes. The files have been copied there but on runtime Ink/Stich doesn't see them. 

So, as a workaround I just copied the files to the user palettes directory. That perfectly works  ~/.config/inkscape/palettes
- cheers ! Daniel
PS: By the way it is a good idea that shortcuts are now language independent, but maybe folks need to know that one should remove localized suffixes.

title: Error when attaching commands to text (not lettering)
body:
Ink/Stitch throws an error when you try to attach a trim command to Inkscape text, when it should just be giving a "don't do that then" message.

How it came up: I selected a stitching line, did a select-same to collect all the other stitching lines. Tried to attach a trim to everything and it threw an internal error. Eventually (we won't talk about how long) I noticed I had "...objects selected of Path and Text..." because my thread color notes off to the side had somehow also acquired the same outline (I always set the text outlines to the same color as the stitching lines, but usually they're solid).

For posterity, the actual error text is:

title: element.py: NoneType attribute error
body:
My typical workflow is to draw linework of my design in the Concepts app on Android, then export that as a DXF. I pull the DXF into Inkscape on Windows 10 and follow the linework to make the actual embroidered design using fills within Inkscape, then run the params tool on these fills. This has been working without issue. 

This time, I exported as an SVG from Concepts rather than a DXF and brought that into Inkscape. I followed the same process as I have in the past after that, but now get the following error when I try to run anything from Ink/Stitch (params, fill tools, etc.) on the image:

title: STOP commands break jef format
body:
Bonjour, j'ai identifié un bug sur inkstitch au sujet des commandes que l'on ajoute aux objets. 

Lorsque j'ai fait ma première numérisation je n'ai pas regroupé les couleurs dans des super objets couleur. 
J'ai juste mis tous les objets dans l'ordre des couleurs dans un seul super objet. (les objets à l'écran avaient des couleurs différentes). Pour être sûre que la machine s'arrête j'avais ajouté des commandes cut et stop pour le dernier objet de la couleur. 
Ca a bien compilé en .jef mais lorsque je rouvrais mon .jef sur inkstitch, tout était de la même couleur et ma machine n'arrivait pas à lire le fichier. 
J'ai donc fait des tests pour identifier l'erreur. Lorsque je transforme mon fichier en pdf il n'y a aucun soucis, il identifie les différentes couleurs, les groupes et les arrêts.
J'ai donc fait des tests et trouvé que la commande STOP ne fonctionne pas correctement. En fait on ne peut ajouter la commande STOP qu'au tout dernier objet qui sera brodé.
Ce qui oblige à classer dans des sous objets les couleurs sinon à la compilation il regroupe tout en une seule couleur.
J'ai vérifié en faisant de multiples tests, si on met le STOP au dernier objet brodé, ça marche, si on met un stop n'importe où ailleurs ça ne fonctionne plus. (on le repère car l'icône ne sait plus créer d'aperçu quand il y a un STOP ailleurs). J'espère que c'est assez clair et que ça aidera. On peut facilement contourner le bug car la machine fait des stop automatiques par couleur. Très bon we à vous et merci pour ce super logiciel !

Nothing happens when I run the menu option; it doesn't cause Inkscape to think the file has changed or anything.

title: divide by zero error in satin column
body: It's possible to get a ZeroDivisionError in `SatinColumn.plot_points_on_rails()` in certain cases.  If one of the sections is exactly 0 mm long, boom.  In my case, this happened because I had a rung doubled up.  Two rungs existed at _exactly_ the same spot.  I think this must have happened because of auto-route satin columns.  Perhaps it was because I ended up running it a second time.

body:
I got this error on the current master branch with inkscape 1.0.1:

    Ink/Stitch experienced an unexpected error.
    If you'd like to help, please file an issue at https://github.com/inkstitch/inkstitch/issues and include the entire error description below: 

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "inkstitch.py", line 44, in <module>
        extension.affect(args=remaining_args)
      File "/usr/share/inkscape/extensions/inkex/deprecated.py", line 181, in affect
        return self.run(args=args)
      File "/usr/share/inkscape/extensions/inkex/base.py", line 140, in run
        self.save_raw(self.effect())
      File "lib/extensions/params.py", line 590, in effect
        frame = SettingsFrame(tabs_factory=self.create_tabs, on_cancel=self.cancel)
      File "lib/extensions/params.py", line 324, in __init__
        self.tabs = self.tabs_factory(self.notebook)
      File "lib/extensions/params.py", line 555, in create_tabs
        nodes_by_class = self.get_nodes_by_class()
      File "lib/extensions/params.py", line 485, in get_nodes_by_class
        nodes = self.get_nodes()
      File "lib/extensions/base.py", line 176, in get_nodes
        return self.descendants(self.document.getroot(), troubleshoot=troubleshoot)
      File "lib/extensions/base.py", line 165, in descendants
        nodes.extend(self.descendants(child, selected, troubleshoot))
      File "lib/extensions/base.py", line 165, in descendants
        nodes.extend(self.descendants(child, selected, troubleshoot))
      File "lib/extensions/base.py", line 147, in descendants
        if element.has_style('display') and element.get_style('display') is None:
      File "lib/elements/element.py", line 184, in has_style
        return self._get_style_raw(style_name) is not None
      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/backports/functools_lru_cache.py", line 113, in wrapper
        result = user_function(*args, **kwds)
      File "lib/elements/element.py", line 167, in _get_style_raw
        style = self.parse_style()
      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/backports/functools_lru_cache.py", line 113, in wrapper
        result = user_function(*args, **kwds)
      File "lib/elements/element.py", line 158, in parse_style
        declarations = tinycss2.parse_declaration_list(node.get("style", ""))
      File ".local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tinycss2/parser.py", line 176, in parse_declaration_list
        tokens = _to_token_iterator(input, skip_comments)
      File ".local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tinycss2/parser.py", line 21, in _to_token_iterator
        return iter(input)
    TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable

This seems to happen when there’s a \<g\> node, just grouping without any styles.

I was able to fix it with this patch:
```diff
diff --git a/lib/elements/element.py b/lib/elements/element.py
index fe1491d8..12f5e9f9 100644
--- a/lib/elements/element.py
+++ b/lib/elements/element.py
@@ -155,7 +155,14 @@ class EmbroideryElement(object):
     def parse_style(self, node=None):
         if node is None:
             node = self.node
-        declarations = tinycss2.parse_declaration_list(node.get("style", ""))
+        style = node.get("style", "")
+        if style is None: style=""
+        declarations = tinycss2.parse_declaration_list(style)
         style = {declaration.lower_name: declaration.value[0].serialize() for declaration in declarations}
         return style

```

title: Auto-route satin columns breaks column without rungs
body:
I have a satin column without rungs (just two straight lines with 2 nodes each). When I autoroute this, in a particular combination with another satin column and have "Preserve order of satin columns" checked, this produces a new column with an unequal number of nodes, and no rungs added.

Problem is shown below. Left is the original, right after applying autoroute with "Preserve order of satin columns" set. The vertical satin is on top, the diagonal and problematic one is on the bottom.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/194491/85989132-6837d300-b9f0-11ea-900b-5fa145e1f701.png)

Removing the extra node (the one above and left of the one pointed at by the troubleshooting arrow) fixes the pattern and makes it simulate as I would expect it to.

Here's the problematic SVG file (gzipped to make github allow it):

[autoroute bug.svg.gz](https://github.com/inkstitch/inkstitch/files/4844544/autoroute.bug.svg.gz)


This was tested with version 1.28.

title: use of u"→" in fonts code causing ascii codec error?
body:
Hey--thanks for this incredible extension!

When I try to add text with inkstitch, I get the following error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/runner/work/inkstitch/inkstitch/lib/extensions/lettering.py", line 241, in apply
  File "/home/runner/work/inkstitch/inkstitch/lib/extensions/lettering.py", line 195, in update_lettering
  File "/home/runner/work/inkstitch/inkstitch/lib/lettering/font.py", line 122, in render_text
  File "/home/runner/work/inkstitch/inkstitch/lib/lettering/font.py", line 95, in _load_variants
  File "/home/runner/work/inkstitch/inkstitch/lib/lettering/font_variant.py", line 52, in __init__
  File "/home/runner/work/inkstitch/inkstitch/lib/lettering/font_variant.py", line 56, in _load_glyphs
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u2192' in position 61: ordinal not in range(128)
```

It looks like this occurs when it tries to handle the `u"→"` in [this file](https://github.com/inkstitch/inkstitch/blob/1e0280db10cbb987842648f78f37bb9acc827305/lib/lettering/font_variant.py#L28-L31). Any idea what might be going on? I'm not totally sure what python version inkstitch is using, but if there's an easy way to programmatically run / test this extension code, I'm happy to dig deeper :).

Here is the docker file I'm using to run it:

<details>

```
FROM ubuntu:16.04

RUN apt-get update && \
    apt-get install -y inkscape unzip python-lxml hicolor-icon-theme --no-install-recommends && \
    rm -rf /var/cache/* && \
    rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

ADD ./inkstitch-refs-tags-v1.27.2-linux-en_US-ff55eccaa4069d9cbcd2dd74890e3797.zip /root/.config/inkscape/extensions/inkstitch.zip

RUN cd /root/.config/inkscape/extensions \
    && unzip inkstitch.zip

VOLUME /images
WORKDIR /images

ENTRYPOINT ["inkscape"]
```

</details>

I run it using these commands my mac, in order to forward X11:

```
xhost + 127.0.0.1
docker build -t inkscape .
docker run -it -v images:/images --rm -e DISPLAY=host.docker.internal:0 inkscape
```

title: simplestyle error
body:
So all day today I was working on digitizing a design. I use ink/stitch on Windows 10. The original design was an SVG created in Adobe illustrator. I don't recall whether or not I created outlines from the letters (AKA in inkscape: object to path). I had 0 error messages with the original file but I didn't like how a certain part of the text stitched out so i downloaded some fonts, and within inkscape I typed out some text... converted that text to a path (object to path) and that's when I got this error message: 

_

> Traceback (most recent call last):
> 
>   File "d:\a\inkstitch\inkstitch\inkstitch.py", line 44, in <module>

> 
>   File "d:\a\inkstitch\inkstitch\lib\elements\element.py", line 148, in has_style
> 
>   File "d:\a\inkstitch\inkstitch\inkscape\share\extensions\simplestyle.py", line 179, in parseStyle
> 
> ValueError: dictionary update sequence element #6 has length 3; 2 is required

_

**After getting this specific error message it will basically corrupt the file and ink/stitch will no longer work for that SVG if you save it.**

I attempted to create a new file, repeat the process of typing the same text, converting the text to path and creating satin columns. Then I get the same error message. I repeated the process a few times using different variations each time.. creating new files, restarting inkscape, typing different text, using different fonts.. same results. At this point I am worried and thought maybe something is wrong inkscape or the plug-in so I re-installed inkscape and downloaded the latest ink/stitch update.

To make sure I installed the new update correctly. I created a new file.. and created two satin columns one manual (two combined parallel lines) and one with the pencil stroke( ink/stitch > satin tools > convert line to satin column) I hit the params, plug-in works fine. . 

I repeated the process of converting text to path (object to path) and got the same error message mentioned above. Heres when I got the theory that maybe the function "Object to path" is causing these issues... so i opened a new file, with the polygon/ellipse tool I created 1 circle and 1 hexagon, then converted those two objects to paths and got these error messages:

**Circle  (Object to path)**

> _path3803: error: Fill: Shape is not valid.  This can happen if the border crosses over itself._

**Polygon  (Object to Path) :**

> _Exception AttributeError: "'NoneType' object has no attribute 'GEOSSTRtree_destroy'" in <bound method STRtree.__del__ of <shapely.strtree.STRtree instance at 0x05F841E8>> ignored_

within this same file, I created a circle and hexagon shape using the bezier pen, hit the params and they work perfectly fine.

title: Sizing issue between Inkscape and machine
body:
Hello,

We're using ink/stitch with a Brother Innovis 800E, and at first were able to determine the size of the embroidery by the sizing in Inkscape (using millimetres). Now the file gets resized, sometimes a lot and sometimes a little - sometimes made bigger, sometimes made smaller - and often we'll get it to the machine to find it's too big to load onto our biggest frame, even though in inkscape, the embroidery looks to be several centimetres below the maximum size.

Is this a known issue? What can we do to prevent it?

title: Converting satin column back to running stitch worked only halfway
body:
I have a mutant hybrid path. It was a satin column that I decided to convert to a bean outline when stitching a smaller version. As best I can remember: I converted the line to dashes, joined the two top nodes so it was a single path, and that was it. Went in to Params and the checkbox was unchecked and everything was grayed out. Checked the box, changed bean to 1, and the preview renders fine. Apply and leave, try to embroider or simulate and it throws an error (an unpretty one, I'm a version behind). Go back to Params and the checkbox is unchecked again, everything is grayed out. Hi,

I have attached the source file, the output pattern and some pictures to illustrate the problem. We are using Windows that is kept up to date.

When the pattern has been embroidered and transferred to the machine, it appears to lose all horizontal movement information. The carriage seems to go up and down only. You can see in the picture of the embroidery the red column that was created by a small amount of the pattern. The blue plastic lid indicates where the pattern should be.

title: Auto Underlay Ignored for Changed Paths
body:
I discovered what I believe is a minor bug. I think the best way to describe it is to explain how I discovered it. 

I had a design with "Auto Underlay" enabled on the "Params" dialog. The design stitched as expected and it came out beautifully with all of the expected underlays.  I then changed one of the path objects by selecting two overlaying paths and doing an Inkscape  Path->Difference operation to subtract one path from the other. I then selected Embroidery->Params again. I verified that the "Auto Underlay" option was still selected and in the preview window I noticed that the path object that I had modified did not show the underlay for only the changed path.  All other paths had the underlay as expected. Just to verify, I sent the .pes file to the sewing machine and it did indeed not do the underlay under only the changed object.  I went back to the "Params" dialog and deselected "Auto Underlay" and then re-selected "Auto Underlay".  After doing this, the preview window showed the underlay under the changed path as well as all of the other paths.  Sending the new .pes file to the machine produced a design with underlay under all expected areas.  So it seems that if you change a path while "Auto Underlay" is enabled, the code will ignore auto underlay for the changed path when producing the stitch plan.

title: Embroider action produces bloated files with return characters
body:
When using the hoops template, if i forget to select the artwork i want to embroider and i chose embroider. it will try to embroider all layers including the ones with the reference artwork for the hoops. Some of those elements are not paths.

It first throws this error

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11083514/40893921-8b882afa-679d-11e8-9f3e-8536e16ec902.png)

After that return characters start to show in the file
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11083514/40893972-e88159b6-679d-11e8-9e6f-bfd864e4fda7.png)


With each call to embroider these return character get exponentially larger

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11083514/40894000-37e0f534-679e-11e8-9d6c-bab910b5ca26.png)

Pretty soon each action we ask start to get slower and slower to the point were it becomes unusable.

In such a case the only solution is to copy the design artwork to a new file save it and discard the old one. copy pasting does not carry the empty return carriage signs from the old file to the new

title: DST output mishandles stitches longer than 12.1mm
body:
DST format can't encode a single stitch or jump that would move the needle more than 12.1mm in the X or Y axis.  libembroidery complains about such stitches but doesn't actually do anything to fix them.

The solution is to add a set of JUMPs before the actual stitch to bridge the gap.  It's probably also a good idea to see if any other formats impose similar limitations, especially if they're smaller.
